reviewText:
NOTE: The online multiplayer in this game is 100% broken, and the online portion is the reason I intended to play this game. The lag I experienced was so bad that you can't even move around without a huge delay. There is a warning when you access the online mode telling you that it's experimental, but you'll only realize this after playing the game. They don't mention it on the store page or anywhere else as far as I know.

AVOID the game at all costs if online MP is all you're looking for. Now, onto reviewing the other parts of the game.

Pros:

- Cool original character designs, nice animations and sprites. Good overall graphics.
- Some of the levels were more challenging than I was expecting and work well with the scorpion get over here" move.
- The AI for the bots is pretty good if you plan on playing the game alone
date:
and in certain game modes provide a good challenge.

Cons:

- Scorpion gimmick gets old fast
recommended: providing maybe an hour or so of gameplay before the fun runs out.\n- Bots sometimes don't attack you after they've stunned you
hoursPlayed: which makes overcoming them a little too easy occasionally.\n- No real incentive to keep you playing
voteText: there's no campaign or rewards for winning. Would be nice if they added unlockable characters
votesHelpful: or literally any kind of reward for progressing. It doesn't even have achievements.\n- As stated before
votesTotal: the online multiplayer is completely broken. I'm willing to try almost any game
votesFunny: no matter how bad it is in online MP so the lack of it is very disappointing.\n\nFor a local multiplayer game
commentsCount: it's probably not too bad but there are much better multiplayer arena games you can play and the scorpion gimmick isn't really adding anything you can't live without. Not worth the $9.99. If you're intent on buying it
column16: only get this if you can get it for $0.50 or in a bundle."

reviewText: Was looking for local co-op games from my library and found this. Gave it a try with my sis and we both agreed that it's a bit too simple. There should be more to the fighting .. perhaps a bigger map/smaller characters/free aim because right now you can just jump or move near enemies and use your kill move (sometimes even if you are stunned).\n\nSo yeah, the idea is good but It needs something more to be enjoyable. I would recommend the game only if you can get it for a discount and if you are looking for a easy co-op game for the younger.

reviewText:
Get Over Here is long on art assets but short on design.  It looks good and sounds good, briefly, but it won't hold your attention long at all.

The first thing you'll probably notice is that the menu is poorly designed.  It accepts mouse-clicks as input, but doesn't acknowledge the pointer, so you'll likely confuse yourself greatly until you realize that the menu must be navigated with keyboard commands.  Don't take your hand off the mouse, though, because you'll need it in play.  And try not to lose track of where the pointer is, which will be tricky, because the pointer is rather small and bland against a very vibrant and cartoony playfield.

You will have a choice from a rogues' gallery of a dozen goofy characters.  It doesn't matter which one you pick, for gameplay purposes -- they perform identically.  Assuming that you actually play more than once, you might want to find one whose attack phrase you find the least annoying.

Gameplay is very simple, and more strategic than it appears at first glance.  Four characters with identical abilities run around in an arena full of hazards.  You want to kill each other in a manner consistent with the match goal (most kills, highest kill streak, whatever) and have only one attack with which to do it.  Your attack is a slow-firing special attack" that kills everyone in a small radius around you
date: but is interruptable.  You also have a hook-shot weapon
recommended: a la Scorpion from Mortal Kombat which targets with the mouse (that's why you're trying not to lose the pointer) and can be used to pull an enemy to you
hoursPlayed: or to pull yourself to an enemy.  Either way
helpfulPercent: giving you an opportunity to get your attack off.  The hook can also pull your enemies into hazards.  You also have a dash move that's good for avoiding hooks -- CPU-controlled characters don't use it much.\n\nBecause your attack is so slow
votesHelpful: strategic play tends to involve prowling around looking for opportunities.  Running up to an enemy and attacking will probably result in a stunning hook to your face
votesTotal: breaking your attack and making you vulnerable to a counter-attack.  Hooking an enemy while he's in the process of attacking someone else
commentsCount: will give you easy prey.\n\nWhen you die
column17: since this is a one-hit kill system
column18: you respawn somewhere on the playfield.  Find yourself quickly
column20: and it's possible for someone to have killed you again before you even see where you are.\n\nPowerups appear on the screen from time to time.  Some change the game briefly but significantly
column21: like the item that puts a temporary moratorium on hooks.  A sword that fills your screen with text is a trap-item.  Other powerups have an imperceptible effect.  I collect them anyway
column22: because grabbing a powerup is a long-conditioned reflex
column23: but I still don't know what half of them do.\n\nThe simplicity of the gameplay suggests that Get Over Here is trying to be like Divekick
column24: a game that is deliberately simple and short on tactical options
column25: to invite the player to really master range and timing.  Unfortunately
column26: I can't see much reason to do so.  NPC opponents are pushovers
column27: and on the rare occasions I can manage to schedule friends to multiplay something
column28: I'd prefer to spend the time something with more depth."

reviewText: It's a cheap game. It doesn't cost much (occasionally available for just a buck), has a bare-bone interface and options with very few game modes. Don't expect too much going in, and you should be pleasantly surprised, because what little is there is very well polished.\n\nIt's a good party game, with very good design, good graphics, and good sound. The gameplay is smooth and simple while still having some depth to it. It's good for some quick simple fun, especially with friends.

reviewText:
I like the nostalgic vibe the game has got!
I played locally with some friends and it's really intense!!
The fact that everyone has got a hook gun creates a lot of tension and gives a lot of room to strategy! It's an easy to learn, but hard to master game!
I like it a lot!
voteText: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I think the game is really fun! The local multiplayer is amazing and the characters are really original!
I wish the game had more single player features, but playing by yourself can get really challenging on Tournament mode!
This game takes the best part of Mobas and put into an party game, just pull your enemies and finish them, that's it!
Long story short, if you like a towerfall, toto temple, bomberman experience then get this game!

reviewText:
A multi-directional shooter with anime inspired characters. Sort of like a mix between tank force and bomberman but worse than both.

Pros:
- It works I guess

Cons:
- Not much to do, just throw a hooks and punch
- Too easy
- Tries too hard to be funny

If you're going to get the game get it cheap or in a bundle like I did.

reviewText: TL;DR: Don't buy this game unless you want to get rid of your friends\n\nThis game is not worth the time you're reading the reviews: the gameplay is no fun; a bunch of display problems (screen size primarily);  it's One Shot Kill Gimmick is awful and there is no real decisions to make.
